reasoning: The critique targets the paper’s skepticism in §4.1 that self-interest (even with convergence on prudential good) will reliably yield a mostly-great future. If mechanism/institution design could robustly align self-interest with “the aggregate good,” that would weaken the paper’s pessimism about the ‘no one aims at the good’ route, but it wouldn’t overturn the paper’s main thrust about low likelihood of WAM-convergence and the conditional, obstacle-laden optimism about moral trade; hence only moderate centrality. The argument itself is suggestive but underdeveloped: it asserts that alignment is a ‘solvable technical problem’ without addressing core difficulties the paper emphasizes or implies (e.g., what objective function institutions should implement given moral disagreement/anti-realism, incentive compatibility under value pluralism, information/commitment problems, capture, and whether ‘aggregate good’ is even well-defined absent convergence). Still, it’s directionally plausible that advanced mechanism design could improve incentive alignment relative to today, so it has some (limited) weakening power. Claims are partly correct but overconfident in calling it merely technical and solvable. The critique is clear, focused on a single issue, and contains little dead weight.
title: Advanced mechanism design could align self-interest with collective welfare
